bjhong02 wrote:
> I set 'hold-queues' to true and 'host-queues-memory-capacity' from 
> 800 to 80. but after about 2-3 minutes, the number of active threads 
> droped to zero. I don't know why. the queued url and used memory are 
> still very low at that time.

Any time you encounter such a 'hung' situation (no progress being made) ,
it would be helpful to check (and collect) the following information
(assuming use on Linux):

(1) Any 'Alerts' in the web UI, especially any 'Serious Error' alerts.

(2) Any unexpected output ('SEVERE' errors or java stack dumps) in
heritrix_out.log or the 'runtime-errors.log'.

(3) The JVM version in use (`java -version`)

(4) The kernel version 9 (`cat /proc/version`)

(5) The version of key libraries, as may be given by these commands:

     `getconf GNU_LIBC_VERSION`
     `getconf GNU_LIBPTHREAD_VERSION`

(6) A Java thread dump, as generated with the SIGQUIT signal
or the Java 1.5 'jstack' utility if available. (Even if 'jstack'
generates error messages to STDERR, it may dump lots of useful
stack info to STDOUT.)

(7) Whether 'top' shows Java process(es) as actively consuming
CPU cycles or not.

Any such hangs that you encounter, we would be interested in seeing all
of the above info.

We've been trying to diagnose several situations where java threads
appear to become stuck, waiting for a notification (after
an IO or synchronization wait) that is never delivered.

- Gordon @ IA
